<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The reaction of AgX (X=ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) acceptors with excesses of tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methane ligands L (L=CH(pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH(4-Mepz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH(3,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH(3,4,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or CH(3-Mepz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(5-Mepz)) yields 1:1 [AgX(L)], 2:1 [Ag(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]X or 3:2 [(AgX)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] complexes. The ligand to metal ratio in all complexes is dependent on the number and disposition of the Me substituents on the azole ring of the neutral ligand and on the nature of the Ag(I) acceptor. All complexes have been characterized in the solid state as well as in solution (medium- and far-IR, <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR and conductivity determinations) and the solid-state structures of [Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>){(pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH}]<ce:inf loc="post">(∞/∞)</ce:inf> and [Ag{(3,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> determined by single crystal X-ray studies.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The reaction of AgX (X=ClO4, NO3 or SO3CH3) acceptors with excesses of tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methane ligands L (L=CH(pz)3, CH(4-Mepz)3, CH(3,5-Me2pz)3, CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 or CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz)) yields 1:1 [AgX(L)], 2:1 [Ag(L)2]X or 3:2 [(AgX)2(L)3] complexes. The ligand to metal ratio in all complexes is dependent on the number and disposition of the Me substituents on the azole ring of the neutral ligand and on the nature of the Ag(I) acceptor. All complexes have been characterized in the solid state as well as in solution (medium- and far-IR, 1H and 13C NMR and conductivity determinations) and the solid-state structures of [Ag(NO3){(pz)3CH}](∞/∞) and [Ag{(3,5-Me2pz)3CH}2]NO3 determined by single crystal X-ray studies.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para view="all">The reaction of AgX (X=ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) acceptors with tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methane ligands L (L=CH(pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH(4-Mepz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH(3,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH(3,4,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or CH(3-Mepz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(5-Mepz)) yields 1:1 [AgX(L)], 2:1 [Ag(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]X or 3:2 [(AgX)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] complexes. [Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH] (1:1) crystallizes with two formula units devoid of crystallographic symmetry as the asymmetric unit of the complex which is an infinite, unsolvated, two-dimensional polymer.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: The reaction of AgX (X=ClO4, NO3 or SO3CH3) acceptors with tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methane ligands L (L=CH(pz)3, CH(4-Mepz)3, CH(3,5-Me2pz)3, CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 or CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz)) yields 1:1 [AgX(L)], 2:1 [Ag(L)2]X or 3:2 [(AgX)2(L)3] complexes. [Ag(NO3)(pz)3CH] (1:1) crystallizes with two formula units devoid of crystallographic symmetry as the asymmetric unit of the complex which is an infinite, unsolvated, two-dimensional polymer.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Since poly(pyrazol-1-yl)borate ligands were discovered and used by Trofimenko, their coordination chemistry has been extensively developed over the last few decades , with particular interest arising out of the ability of this class of ligands to modify or control the steric and electronic environment about the metal center by variation of the pyrazolyl groups.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since poly(pyrazol-1-yl)borate ligands were discovered and used by Trofimenko, their coordination chemistry has been extensively developed over the last few decades , with particular interest arising out of the ability of this class of ligands to modify or control the steric and electronic environment about the metal center by variation of the pyrazolyl groups.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Recently this group has focused on contrasting the chemistry of complexes of the neutral poly(pyrazol-1-yl)alkane ligands with that previously developed for anionic poly(pyrazol-1-yl)borates, in extension of which we have initiated a study of the coordination chemistry of neutral bis- and tris(pyrazol-1-yl)alkanes with several post-transition and transition metals . While in the last years numerous reports of poly(pyrazol-1-yl)borate–Ag(I) complexes have appeared , to date the chemistry of poly(pyrazol-1-yl)alkanes toward transition metals remains relatively unexplored.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently this group has focused on contrasting the chemistry of complexes of the neutral poly(pyrazol-1-yl)alkane ligands with that previously developed for anionic poly(pyrazol-1-yl)borates, in extension of which we have initiated a study of the coordination chemistry of neutral bis- and tris(pyrazol-1-yl)alkanes with several post-transition and transition metals . While in the last years numerous reports of poly(pyrazol-1-yl)borate-Ag(I) complexes have appeared , to date the chemistry of poly(pyrazol-1-yl)alkanes toward transition metals remains relatively unexplored.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In previous papers we have described interactions between Ag(I) and N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-donors which have given a picture different from that obtained when other acceptors were employed . In particular, strongly distorted tetrahedral complexes of general formula [(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-donor)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag]X were obtained also when very weakly basic ligands, such as bis(4-nitropyrazol-1-yl)alkane, were used, possibly consequent on π-backdonation between a pyrazole nitrogen and silver , not found with Zn, Cd, Sn, Ni and Hg .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In previous papers we have described interactions between Ag(I) and N2-donors which have given a picture different from that obtained when other acceptors were employed . In particular, strongly distorted tetrahedral complexes of general formula [(N2-donor)2Ag]X were obtained also when very weakly basic ligands, such as bis(4-nitropyrazol-1-yl)alkane, were used, possibly consequent on π-backdonation between a pyrazole nitrogen and silver , not found with Zn, Cd, Sn, Ni and Hg .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">As an extension of this work, we now describe a study of the donor behavior of neutral, tris-chelating, flexible, stable N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-donor tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methanes towards Ag(I) acceptors. With the aim of evaluating the importance of the substituents on the structure and properties of the concomitant Ag(I) complexes, we have prepared a series of ligands defined by the presence of methyl groups in the 3-, 4- and 5-positions of the pyrazole ring CH(pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH(4-Mepz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH(3,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH(3,4,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or CH(3-Mepz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(5-Mepz) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>). We have shown that different reaction patterns may be found depending on the nature of the donor and of the Ag(I) acceptor. In order to gain insight into the factors controlling the structure and bonding in these complexes, and to synthesize complexes in which the same ligand may be coordinated to different metal centers, we have employed Ag(I) incorporating weakly donating oxyanions (ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As an extension of this work, we now describe a study of the donor behavior of neutral, tris-chelating, flexible, stable N3-donor tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methanes towards Ag(I) acceptors. With the aim of evaluating the importance of the substituents on the structure and properties of the concomitant Ag(I) complexes, we have prepared a series of ligands defined by the presence of methyl groups in the 3-, 4- and 5-positions of the pyrazole ring CH(pz)3, CH(4-Mepz)3, CH(3,5-Me2pz)3, CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 or CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) ( ). We have shown that different reaction patterns may be found depending on the nature of the donor and of the Ag(I) acceptor. In order to gain insight into the factors controlling the structure and bonding in these complexes, and to synthesize complexes in which the same ligand may be coordinated to different metal centers, we have employed Ag(I) incorporating weakly donating oxyanions (ClO4 -, NO3 - and SO3CH3 -).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">We report here the syntheses and properties of 15 new complexes. The solid-state structures for the derivatives [Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>){(pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH}]<ce:inf loc="post">(∞/∞)</ce:inf>, an infinite, unsolvated two-dimensional polymer containing a bridging tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methane ligand, and [Ag{(3,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, have been determined by single crystal X-ray studies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We report here the syntheses and properties of 15 new complexes. The solid-state structures for the derivatives [Ag(NO3){(pz)3CH}](∞/∞), an infinite, unsolvated two-dimensional polymer containing a bridging tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methane ligand, and [Ag{(3,5-Me2pz)3CH}2]NO3, have been determined by single crystal X-ray studies.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The Ag(I) salts were purchased from Aldrich (Milwaukee) and used as received. Solvent evaporations were carried out under vacuum with the use of a rotary evaporator. The samples for microanalysis were dried in vacuo to constant weight (20 °C, ca. 0.1 Torr). All syntheses were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere. Hydrocarbon solvents were dried by distillation from sodium–potassium, dichloromethane from calcium hydride and tetrahydrofuran from sodium and benzophenone. All solvents were degassed with dry nitrogen prior to use.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

The Ag(I) salts were purchased from Aldrich (Milwaukee) and used as received. Solvent evaporations were carried out under vacuum with the use of a rotary evaporator. The samples for microanalysis were dried in vacuo to constant weight (20 °C, ca. 0.1 Torr). All syntheses were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere. Hydrocarbon solvents were dried by distillation from sodium-potassium, dichloromethane from calcium hydride and tetrahydrofuran from sodium and benzophenone. All solvents were degassed with dry nitrogen prior to use.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Elemental analyses (C, H, N, S) were performed with a Fisons Instruments 1108 CHNSO Elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded from 4000 to 100 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> with a Perkin–Elmer System 2000 FT–IR instrument. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra were recorded using a VXR-300 Varian spectrometer operating at room temperature (300 MHz for <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H). <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AC200 spectrometer operating at 50 MHz with a multinuclear 10 mm probehead at room temperature. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra chemical shifts are referred to the residual proton or carbon resonance of the deuterated solvents relative to TMS. Peaks multiplicities are abbreviated: singlet, s; doublet, d; triplet, t; multiplet, m; pseudotriplet, pt; complex multiplet, mc; broad, br. Melting points are uncorrected and were taken on an IA 8100 Electrothermal instrument and on a capillary apparatus. The electrical conductance of the solutions was measured with a Crison CDTM 522 conductimeter at room temperature.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Elemental analyses (C, H, N, S) were performed with a Fisons Instruments 1108 CHNSO Elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded from 4000 to 100 cm-1 with a Perkin-Elmer System 2000 FT-IR instrument. 1H NMR spectra were recorded using a VXR-300 Varian spectrometer operating at room temperature (300 MHz for 1H). 13C NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AC200 spectrometer operating at 50 MHz with a multinuclear 10 mm probehead at room temperature. 1H and 13C NMR spectra chemical shifts are referred to the residual proton or carbon resonance of the deuterated solvents relative to TMS. Peaks multiplicities are abbreviated: singlet, s; doublet, d; triplet, t; multiplet, m; pseudotriplet, pt; complex multiplet, mc; broad, br. Melting points are uncorrected and were taken on an IA 8100 Electrothermal instrument and on a capillary apparatus. The electrical conductance of the solutions was measured with a Crison CDTM 522 conductimeter at room temperature.

[Ag{(pz)3CH}CH3OH)]ClO4 (1)

To a stirred methanol solution (30 ml) of HC(pz)3 (0.210 g, 0.981 mmol) at r.t., under nitrogen in a round-bottomed flask protected from the light, AgClO4 (0.110 g, 0.53 mmol) was added. After approximately 12 h, the colorless precipitate formed was filtered off and washed with diethyl ether to give (27% yield) the analytical sample 1. M.p.: 262-263 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 3.5 (s, 3H, CH 3OH), 6.39 (pt, 3H, 4-CH), 7.68, 7.83 (2 d, 6H, 3- and 5-CH), 9.10 (s, 1H, CH). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 3.35 (s, 3H, CH 3OH), 6.46 (pt, 3H, 4-CH), 7.70, 8.00 (2 s, 6H, 3- and 5-CH), 9.09 (s, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 141.7, (3-CH), 131.0 (5-CH), 107.0 (4-CH), 80.6 (CH). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=1.01×10-3 M): Λ 0.45 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 28.8; H, 2.9; N, 18.8. Calc. for C11H14AgClN6O5: C, 29.1; H, 3.1; N, 18.5%. IR (cm-1): 3564 sbr [ν(OH)], 3103 br, 3156 s, 3124 br, 3103 br [ν(CH)], 1116 sbr, 1106 sbr, 1097 sbr, 1070 sbr, 642 s, 621 s, 610 sh [ν(ClO4)].

elements.clean_text:
Structure determinations

For [Ag(NO3){(pz)3CH}](∞/∞), a unique single counter data set was measured (T ca. 295 K; 2θ max=50°) yielding N=4653 independent reflections, N o=2253 with I>3σ(I) being considered ‘observed', gaussian absorption correction being applied. For [Ag{(3,5-Me2pz)3CH}2]NO3⋅H2O, a full sphere of CCD area detector data was measured (T ca. 153 K; ω-scans, 2θ max=58°), 20 897 reflections merging to N=4581 (R int=0.022) after ‘empirical'/multiscan absorption correction, N o (F>4σ(F))=3757. Anisotropic thermal parameter forms were refined for the non-hydrogen atoms, conventional residuals R, R w (statistical weights) on |F| being quoted. Pertinent results are given in   and     , the latter showing 20 (T ca. 295 K), 50% (T ca. 153 K) displacement amplitudes for the non-hydrogen atoms, hydrogen atoms having arbitrary radii of 0.1 Å.

elements.clean_text: In the latter compound, as modeled in space group P21/c, the nitrate was modeled as disordered about a center of symmetry, its disorder concerted with that of a companion water molecule at the symmetry related site. Available specimens were rather small, the present CCD determination being preceded by an inferior room temperature study with data from a single counter instrument, no non-trivial differences being found between the two studies. At approximately 295 K, a=8.962(2), b=12.819(3), c=16.191(3) Å, β=92.59(2)°, V=1858 Å3, D calc=1.370 g cm-3.

Results and discussion

Syntheses and properties

The interaction between Ag(I) acceptors AgX (X=ClO4, NO3 or CH3SO3) and CH(pz)3, CH(4-Mepz)3, CH(3,5-Me2pz)3, CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 or CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) in methanol or benzene always resulted in compounds 1-15 independently of reaction conditions and acceptor:ligand ratio employed (). <ce:para view="all">The analytical and spectral data of the tris(pyrazolyl)methane ligands and their complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>15</ce:bold> are listed in .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">All complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>15</ce:bold> are colorless solids and their stabilities in air and at room temperature differ depending on the nature of the ligand and of the counterion. All derivatives, when exposed to atmosphere decompose yielding metallic silver. The derivatives of AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> decompose rapidly; those containing the HC(3,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and HC(3,4,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> ligands are the most stable.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The analytical and spectral data of the tris(pyrazolyl)methane ligands and their complexes 1-15 are listed in .

All complexes 1-15 are colorless solids and their stabilities in air and at room temperature differ depending on the nature of the ligand and of the counterion. All derivatives, when exposed to atmosphere decompose yielding metallic silver. The derivatives of AgNO3 decompose rapidly; those containing the HC(3,5-Me2pz)3 and HC(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 ligands are the most stable.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">All the complexes show good solubility in methanol, chlorinated solvents and acetone, exceptions being found in derivatives <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>10</ce:bold>, which are poorly soluble in chlorinated solvents, probably due to their poly- or oligomeric nature (see below). They are stable in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> or methanol, whereas in chloroform solutions they slowly decompose with deposition of Ag(0). An exception is represented by the complex [Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>){(pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH}]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), which readily decomposes in methanol solution, in a nitrogen atmosphere and in the dark; in fact derivative <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has been obtained only using benzene as reaction solvent.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: All the complexes show good solubility in methanol, chlorinated solvents and acetone, exceptions being found in derivatives 1, 2 and 10, which are poorly soluble in chlorinated solvents, probably due to their poly- or oligomeric nature (see below). They are stable in CH2Cl2 or methanol, whereas in chloroform solutions they slowly decompose with deposition of Ag(0). An exception is represented by the complex [Ag(NO3){(pz)3CH}]⋅H2O (2), which readily decomposes in methanol solution, in a nitrogen atmosphere and in the dark; in fact derivative 2 has been obtained only using benzene as reaction solvent.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>15</ce:bold> display 1:1 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>10</ce:bold>), 2:1 (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold>) and 3:2 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>11</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>14</ce:bold>) ligand to metal ratios. The stoichiometries of the final products are influenced by the nature of the counterion and by the number and the location of methyl groups in the pyrazole rings of the ligands independently of the acceptor:ligand ratio used, the greater ligand to metal ratio being found when the more basic donors such as CH(3,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or CH(3,4,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or the less coordinating anions such as ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> or SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> were employed. The complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold>, for which a 2:1 ligand to metal ratio has been found, likely have a mononuclear structure as that in , as also confirmed by the X-ray single crystal study of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, whereas a poly- or oligonuclear structure with bridging tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methane and/or weakly coordinating anions, as in the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (see below), appears probable for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>12</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>14</ce:bold> ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The compounds 1-15 display 1:1 (1, 2 and 10), 2:1 (3-7, 13 and 15) and 3:2 (8, 9, 11, 12 and 14) ligand to metal ratios. The stoichiometries of the final products are influenced by the nature of the counterion and by the number and the location of methyl groups in the pyrazole rings of the ligands independently of the acceptor:ligand ratio used, the greater ligand to metal ratio being found when the more basic donors such as CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 or CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 or the less coordinating anions such as ClO4 or SO3CH3 were employed. The complexes 3-7, 13 and 15, for which a 2:1 ligand to metal ratio has been found, likely have a mononuclear structure as that in , as also confirmed by the X-ray single crystal study of 5, whereas a poly- or oligonuclear structure with bridging tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methane and/or weakly coordinating anions, as in the structure of 2 (see below), appears probable for compounds 1, 2, 8-12, and 14 ().

elements.content:
Conductivity measurements (see ) were carried out in CH2Cl2 for all the derivatives 1–15. The derivatives of CH(pz)3 and CH(4-Mepz)3 are non-electrolytes in CH2Cl2 whereas those of CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 and CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3, the most basic and the most sterically hindered ligands, exhibit conductivity values in CH2Cl2 typical of a 1:1 electrolyte. Finally the derivatives of CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) 13 and 14 are partly ionized in CH2Cl2 solution whereas the derivative 15 is a non-electrolyte in the same solvent. The 2:1 complexes 3–6 and 15 for which an ionic structure has been hypothesized in the solid state likely undergo a dissociation with concomitant re-association of the O-donor coordinating anion (). (2) [(L)2 Ag]+[X]− →
    solvent
[LAgX]+L
elements.clean_text: Conductivity measurements (see ) were carried out in CH2Cl2 for all the derivatives 1-15. The derivatives of CH(pz)3 and CH(4-Mepz)3 are non-electrolytes in CH2Cl2 whereas those of CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 and CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3, the most basic and the most sterically hindered ligands, exhibit conductivity values in CH2Cl2 typical of a 1:1 electrolyte. Finally the derivatives of CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) 13 and 14 are partly ionized in CH2Cl2 solution whereas the derivative 15 is a non-electrolyte in the same solvent. The 2:1 complexes 3-6 and 15 for which an ionic structure has been hypothesized in the solid state likely undergo a dissociation with concomitant re-association of the O-donor coordinating anion (). elements.content: <ce:section-title>Spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>IR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Selected IR data of the free donors and their corresponding Ag(I) complexes are listed in . In the regions 3200–3000 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 1650–1500 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, the ligands exhibit weak bands typical of CH stretching and a number of more intense absorptions due to ring breathing modes, respectively . These absorptions are not markedly shifted upon coordination of the ligand to Ag(I), suggesting a weak influence of the complexation on the absorptions within the donor.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopy

IR spectra

Selected IR data of the free donors and their corresponding Ag(I) complexes are listed in . In the regions 3200-3000 cm-1 and 1650-1500 cm-1, the ligands exhibit weak bands typical of CH stretching and a number of more intense absorptions due to ring breathing modes, respectively . These absorptions are not markedly shifted upon coordination of the ligand to Ag(I), suggesting a weak influence of the complexation on the absorptions within the donor.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The perchlorato derivatives <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>13</ce:bold>, having a 2:1 ligand to metal ratio, show a strong and broad absorption at approximately 1100–1080 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and a sharp medium or strong absorption at approximately 625 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. These vibrations indicate the presence of ionic perchlorato groups  in accordance with the proposed structures (see below). On the other hand, the perchlorato derivatives <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>10</ce:bold>, with 1:1 ligand to metal ratio show two or three strong and broad absorptions at approximately 1130–1070 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and sharp medium or strong absorption at approximately 625 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. These vibrations indicate the presence of perchlorato groups coordinated to silver in accordance with the structures proposed. In the spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> a broad absorption at approximately 3560 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is due to the OH stretching of the likely coordinated methanol molecule.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The perchlorato derivatives 4, 7 and 13, having a 2:1 ligand to metal ratio, show a strong and broad absorption at approximately 1100-1080 cm-1, and a sharp medium or strong absorption at approximately 625 cm-1. These vibrations indicate the presence of ionic perchlorato groups  in accordance with the proposed structures (see below). On the other hand, the perchlorato derivatives 1 and 10, with 1:1 ligand to metal ratio show two or three strong and broad absorptions at approximately 1130-1070 cm-1 and sharp medium or strong absorption at approximately 625 cm-1. These vibrations indicate the presence of perchlorato groups coordinated to silver in accordance with the structures proposed. In the spectrum of 1 a broad absorption at approximately 3560 cm-1 is due to the OH stretching of the likely coordinated methanol molecule.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The nitrato derivatives <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>14</ce:bold> show broad absorptions in the range 1310–1400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and a strong absorption at approximately 700–768 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The IR spectra may be indicative of the coordination mode of the nitrato groups , but in our case the NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> absorptions are overlapped with some absorptions due to the N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-donor ligand, so that the spectroscopic data does not afford reliable information.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The nitrato derivatives 2, 5, 8, 11 and 14 show broad absorptions in the range 1310-1400 cm-1 and a strong absorption at approximately 700-768 cm-1. The IR spectra may be indicative of the coordination mode of the nitrato groups , but in our case the NO3 absorptions are overlapped with some absorptions due to the N3-donor ligand, so that the spectroscopic data does not afford reliable information.

elements.clean_text:
NMR spectra

The 1H NMR spectra of the ligand and of the Ag(I) complexes (1-15) were recorded in CDCl3 and, for some derivatives, in CD3OD and DMSO, as dictated by solubility considerations.

In the spectra of the derivatives of CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 4-6 and HC(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 7-9, the Δ values (Δ=difference in chemical shift for the same type of proton in the free base and in its Ag(I) complex) are small, consistent with a large dissociation of the complexes in solution (Δ=0.21-0.25 ppm for the methyls in the 3- and 5-positions of the pyrazole ring; Δ=0.1-0.2 ppm for the bridging CH proton in the CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 derivatives).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Finally, it is of interest to observe that the greater Δ (0.6–0.8 ppm) values for the 5-CH protons have been found in the derivatives of CH(3-Mepz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(5-Mepz) <ce:bold>13</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>15</ce:bold>.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">In the spectra of derivatives <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold> the resonance due to the methanesulphonate protons falls in the range 2.76–2.92 ppm.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">In all complexes only one signal is detected for each equivalent group of protons (or for the corresponding carbon atoms) showing that the boat-shaped six-membered rings are not rigid, the rings formed upon chelation becoming magnetically equivalent through rapid inversion or breaking of the AgN bonds. Our hypothesis has been supported by <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR experiments. For example the proton NMR spectrum of derivative <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, recorded also at −50 °C both in the presence or absence of excess N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-donor ligand, exhibits only one set of signals and the chemical shifts were in the middle between those of the pure ligand and those of the starting complex.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Finally, it is of interest to observe that the greater Δ (0.6-0.8 ppm) values for the 5-CH protons have been found in the derivatives of CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) 13-15.

In the spectra of derivatives 3, 6, 9, 12 and 15 the resonance due to the methanesulphonate protons falls in the range 2.76-2.92 ppm.

In all complexes only one signal is detected for each equivalent group of protons (or for the corresponding carbon atoms) showing that the boat-shaped six-membered rings are not rigid, the rings formed upon chelation becoming magnetically equivalent through rapid inversion or breaking of the AgN bonds. Our hypothesis has been supported by 1H NMR experiments. For example the proton NMR spectrum of derivative 5, recorded also at -50 °C both in the presence or absence of excess N3-donor ligand, exhibits only one set of signals and the chemical shifts were in the middle between those of the pure ligand and those of the starting complex.

elements.clean_text: The spectra of the 1:1 derivatives 1, 2 and 10, recorded in DMSO because of solubility considerations, show a line-width typical of a polynuclear structure, as in the case of 2, also confirmed by single crystal X-ray studies.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra of the ligands and of the Ag(I) complexes (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>15</ce:bold>) were recorded in CDCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or DMSO. The carbon ring signals are shifted downfield upon complexation; negligible displacement was observed for the methyl carbons and a displacement to higher field was always observed for the CH bridging carbons, this displacement ranging from approximately 2–3 ppm in derivatives of CH(4-Mepz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> to approximately 10 ppm in the derivatives containing the more sterically hindered ligands CH(3,4,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and CH(3,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The 13C NMR spectra of the ligands and of the Ag(I) complexes (1-15) were recorded in CDCl3 or DMSO. The carbon ring signals are shifted downfield upon complexation; negligible displacement was observed for the methyl carbons and a displacement to higher field was always observed for the CH bridging carbons, this displacement ranging from approximately 2-3 ppm in derivatives of CH(4-Mepz)3 to approximately 10 ppm in the derivatives containing the more sterically hindered ligands CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 and CH(3,5-Me2pz)3.

The two independent silver atoms have different environments ((a)) with both neutral ligands and anionic nitrates playing a role in knitting symmetry related metal atoms into the polymer sheet. Ag(2) has a tris(bidentate) environment, comprising pairs of pyrazolate N(2) donors from each of the independent pz<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH ligands coordinating as chelates (nitrate 2 being the third through O(21,22)) with the third pyrazolate ring pendant and coordinating to an Ag(1) atom in each case. The chelate from ligand 2 is more symmetrically coordinated than that from ligand 1, with the silver atom more nearly coplanar with the pyrazolate rings. elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The results of the two single-crystal X-ray studies provide examples of complexes of AgNO3:L (L=(R n pz)3CH) 1:1 and 1:2 stoichiometries, for R n =H n  and R n =3,5-Me2, respectively.

[Ag(NO3)(pz)3CH] (1:1) (2) crystallizes with two formula units devoid of crystallographic symmetry as the asymmetric unit of the complex which is an infinite, unsolvated, two-dimensional polymer lying parallel to the ac plane (). The two independent silver atoms have different environments ((a)) with both neutral ligands and anionic nitrates playing a role in knitting symmetry related metal atoms into the polymer sheet. Ag(2) has a tris(bidentate) environment, comprising pairs of pyrazolate N(2) donors from each of the independent pz3CH ligands coordinating as chelates (nitrate 2 being the third through O(21,22)) with the third pyrazolate ring pendant and coordinating to an Ag(1) atom in each case. The chelate from ligand 2 is more symmetrically coordinated than that from ligand 1, with the silver atom more nearly coplanar with the pyrazolate rings. The nitrate chelation is slightly unsymmetrical, the more tightly bound O(21) bifurcating so that with O(23), feebly bound, it chelates also to Ag(1). Of the nitrate oxygens O(11) is the most tightly bound, pendant as a terminal ligand from Ag(1) also; the environment of Ag(1) is thus Ag(bidentate)(unidentate)3.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">By contrast only one half of the formula unit of the ionic 1:2 adduct [Ag{(3,5-Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), comprises the asymmetric unit of that structure, the cation disposed with the silver atom on a crystallographic inversion center () and the anion modeled as disordered about another in space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. Here, each ligand behaves as a tripod ((b)), albeit seemingly rather uncomfortably accommodating interligand substituent clashes, particularly evident in the deviation of the silver atom out of ligand plane 3 (the plane with the longest AgN bond). The overall lattice disposition is similar to but not isomorphous to those recorded for numerous other [M(<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-tripod)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](oxyanion)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> arrays .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: By contrast only one half of the formula unit of the ionic 1:2 adduct [Ag{(3,5-Me2pz)3CH}2]NO3⋅H2O (5), comprises the asymmetric unit of that structure, the cation disposed with the silver atom on a crystallographic inversion center () and the anion modeled as disordered about another in space group P21/c. Here, each ligand behaves as a tripod ((b)), albeit seemingly rather uncomfortably accommodating interligand substituent clashes, particularly evident in the deviation of the silver atom out of ligand plane 3 (the plane with the longest AgN bond). The overall lattice disposition is similar to but not isomorphous to those recorded for numerous other [M(N 3-tripod)2](oxyanion)2 arrays .

Syntheses

Syntheses of the ligands

Tris(pyrazol-1-yl)methane CH(pz)3 

The ligand CH(pz)3 (44% yield) was obtained according to the published method . 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 6.37 (pt, 3H, 4-CH), 7.58 (d, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.68 (d, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 8.43 (s, 1H, CH). 1H NMR (acetone-d6): δ 6.40 (pt, 3H, 4-CH), 7.63 (d, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.86 (d, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 8.74 (s, 1H, CH). 1H NMR (CD3OD): δ 6.43 (t, 3H, 4-CH), 7.67 (d, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.74 (d, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 8.70 (s, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 142.2 (3-C (pz)), 130.0 (5-C (pz)), 107.2 (4-C (pz)), 83.6 (CH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 141.2 (3-C (pz)), 130.4 (5-C (pz)), 107.8 (4-C (pz)), 81.9 (CH).

Tris(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)methane CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 

The ligand CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 (42% yield) was obtained according to the published method . 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.01 (s, 9H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.18 (s, 9H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 5.88 (s, 3H, 4-CH), 8.09 (s, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 147.3 (3-C (pz)), 140.2 (5-C (pz)), 107.4 (4-C (pz)), 80.0 (CH) 13.7, 10.6 (3- and 5-CH3).

Tris(3,4,5-trimethylpyrazol-1-yl)methane CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 

The ligand CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 (44% yield) was obtained according to the published method . 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.88 (s, 9H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 1.93 (s, 9H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.13 (s, 9H, 4-CH 3), 8.05 (s, 1H, CH). 1H NMR (CD3OD): δ 1.92 (s, 18H, 3- and 5-CH 3), 2.12 (s, 9H, 4-CH 3), 8.09 (s, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 147.7 (3-C (pz)), 137.0 (5-C (pz)), 113.4 (4-C (pz)), 81.2 (CH), 12.4, 9.4, 8.1 (3-, 4- and 5-CH3)).

Tris(4-methylpyrazol-1-yl)methane CH(4-Mepz)3 

The ligand CH(4-Mepz)3 (44% yield) was obtained according to the published method . 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.06 (s, 9H, 4-CH 3), 7.30 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.46 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 8.17 (s, 1H, CH). 1H NMR (CD3OD): δ 2.07 (s, 9H, 4-CH 3), 7.44 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.47 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 8.36 (s, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 142.9 (3-C (pz)), 128.2 (5-C (pz)), 118.2 (4-C (pz)), 83.8 (CH), 9.4 (4-CH3). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 141.6 (3-C (pz)), 128.4 (5-C (pz)), 116.8 (4-C (pz)), 82.0 (CH), 8.8 (4-CH3).

Bis(3-methylpyrazol-1-yl)(5-methylpyrazol-1-yl)methane CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz)

The ligand CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) (44% yield) was obtained according to the published method . 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.28 (s, 6H, 3-CH 3), 2.40 (s, 3H, 5-CH 3), 6.11 (d, 3H, 4-CH), 7.31 (d, 2H, 5-CH), 7.54 (d, 1H, 3-CH), 8.21 (s, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 150.7 (3-CCH3 (pz)), 141.1 (3-C (pz)), 139.8 (5-CCH3 (pz)), 129.7 (5-C (pz)), 107.1 (4-C (pz)), 80.4 (CH), 13.7, 10.8 (3- and 5-CH3).

Synthesis of the complexes

[Ag{(pz)3CH}CH3OH)]ClO4 (1)

To a stirred methanol solution (30 ml) of HC(pz)3 (0.210 g, 0.981 mmol) at r.t., under nitrogen in a round-bottomed flask protected from the light, AgClO4 (0.110 g, 0.53 mmol) was added. After approximately 12 h, the colorless precipitate formed was filtered off and washed with diethyl ether to give (27% yield) the analytical sample 1. M.p.: 262-263 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 3.5 (s, 3H, CH 3OH), 6.39 (pt, 3H, 4-CH), 7.68, 7.83 (2 d, 6H, 3- and 5-CH), 9.10 (s, 1H, CH). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 3.35 (s, 3H, CH 3OH), 6.46 (pt, 3H, 4-CH), 7.70, 8.00 (2 s, 6H, 3- and 5-CH), 9.09 (s, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 141.7, (3-CH), 131.0 (5-CH), 107.0 (4-CH), 80.6 (CH). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=1.01×10-3 M): Λ 0.45 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 28.8; H, 2.9; N, 18.8. Calc. for C11H14AgClN6O5: C, 29.1; H, 3.1; N, 18.5%. IR (cm-1): 3564 sbr [ν(OH)], 3103 br, 3156 s, 3124 br, 3103 br [ν(CH)], 1116 sbr, 1106 sbr, 1097 sbr, 1070 sbr, 642 s, 621 s, 610 sh [ν(ClO4)].

[Ag{(pz)3CH}2]SO3CH3⋅H2O (3)

To a stirred methanol solution (30 ml) of CH(pz)3 (0.210 g, 0.981 mmol) at r.t., under nitrogen in a round-bottomed flask protected from the light, Ag(SO3CH3) (0.100 g, 0.493 mmol) was added. After approximately 12 h the solvent was removed with a rotary evaporator. To the residue was added diethyl ether (50 ml) and the reaction was carried out with stirring and at r.t. for 12 h; the colorless precipitate formed was filtered off and washed with diethyl ether to give (72% yield) the analytical sample 3. M.p.: 161-163 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.9 (br, 2H, H 2O), 2.88 (s, 3H, SO3CH 3), 6.31 (pt, 6H, 4-CH), 7.59, 8.16 (2 d, 12H, 3- and 5-CH), 9.53 (s, 2H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 142.6, (3-CH), 131.7 (5-CH), 107.3 (4-CH), 80.9 (CH), 39.5 (SO3CH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=0.99×10-3 M): Λ 1.54 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 38.5; H, 3.7; N, 25.1; S, 5.4. Calc. for C21H25AgN12O4S: C, 38.8; H, 3.9; N, 25.9; S, 4.9%. IR (cm-1): 3400 br [ν(H2O)], 3126 br, 3112 br, 3096 br [ν(CH)].

[Ag{(3,5-Me2pz)3CH}2]ClO4 (4)

To a stirred methanol solution (30 ml) of CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 (0.300 g, 1.005 mmol) at r.t., under nitrogen in a round-bottomed flask protected from the light, AgClO4 (0.110 g, 0.531 mmol) was added. After approximately 12 h, the colorless precipitate formed was filtered off and washed with diethyl ether to give (98% yield) the analytical sample 4. M.p.: 319 °C (dec.). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.89 (m, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.39 (m, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 5.91 (s, 6H, 4-CH), 7.92 (s, 2H, CH). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 1.85 (s, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.36 (s, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 5.90 (s, 6H, 4-CH), 8.01 (s, 2H, CH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 149.7 (3-CCH3), 140.9 (5-CCH3), 106.9 (4-CH), 71.8 (CH), 13.0, 10.3 (3- or 5-CH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=1.09×10-3 M): Λ 51.1 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 47.5; H, 5.7; N, 20.7. Calc. for C32H44AgClN12O4: C, 47.8; H, 5.5; N, 20.9%. IR (cm-1): 3187 w, 3106 w, [ν(CH)], 1090 sbr, 632 sh, 623 s [ν(ClO4)].

[Ag{(3,5-Me2pz)3CH}2]NO3⋅H2O (5)

Compound 5 (24% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 4. M.p.: 299-300 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.82 (br, 2H, H 2O), 1.93 (s, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.41 (s, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 5.90 (s, 6H, 4-CH), 7.98 (s, 2H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 150.3 (3-CCH3), 140.3 (5-CCH3), 107.1 (4-CH), 72.2 (CH), 13.3, 10.8 (3- or 5-CH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=0.99×10-3 M): Λ 36.0 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 48.8; H, 6.0; N, 23.2. Calc. for C32H46AgN13O4: C, 49.0; H, 5.9; N, 23.2%. IR (cm-1): 3200 br [ν(H2O)], 3128 w, 3094 w [ν(CH)], 1316 sbr, 720 s [ν(NO3)].

[Ag{(3,5-Me2pz)3CH}2]SO3CH3 (6)

Compound 6 (91% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 3, using CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 as ligand. M.p.: 270-271 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.90 (s, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.43 (s, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.76 (s, 3H, SO3CH 3), 5.89 (s, 6H, 4-CH), 7.93 (s, 2H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 150.5, (3-CCH3), 140.1 (5-CCH3), 107.1 (4-CH), 71.3 (CH), 39.4 (SO3CH3), 13.3, 11.0 (3- or 5-CH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=1.03×10-3 M): Λ 50.7 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 49.3; H, 6.1; N, 20.6; S, 4.0. Calc. for C33H47AgN12O3S: C, 49.6; H, 5.9; N, 21.0; S, 4.0%. IR (cm-1): 3189 w, 3125 w, [ν(CH)].

[Ag{(3,4,5-Me3pz)3CH}2]ClO4 (7)

Compound 7 (74% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 4 using HC(3,4,5-Me3pz)3 as ligand. M.p.: 296 °C (dec.). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.79 (s, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 1.86 (s, 18H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.35 (s, 18H, 4-CH 3), 7.92 (s, 2H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 149.5, (3-CCH3), 136.4 (5-CCH3), 113.3 (4-CCH3), 71.7 (CH), 11.5, 9.5, 7.8 (3- or 4- or 5-CH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=0.99×10-3 M): Λ 47.9 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 51.2; H, 6.7; N, 18.9. Calc. for C38H56AgClN12O4: C, 51.4; H, 6.4; N, 18.9. IR (cm-1): 3158 w [ν(CH)], 1081 sbr, 624 s [ν(ClO4)].

[(AgNO3)2{(3,4,5-Me3pz)3CH}3] (8)

To a stirred methanol solution (30 ml) of CH(3,4,5-Me2pz)3 (0.340 g, 1.00 mmol) at r.t., under nitrogen in a round-bottomed flask protected from the light, AgNO3 (0.085 g, 0.500 mmol) was added. After approximately 12 h the solvent was removed with a rotary evaporator. To the residue diethyl ether (50 ml) was added and the reaction was carried out with stirring at r.t. for 12 h; the colorless precipitate formed was filtered off and washed with diethyl ether to give (72% yield) the analytical sample 8. M.p.: 205 °C (dec.). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.86 (s, 27H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.06 (s, 27H, 3- or 5-CH 3), 2.35 (s, 27H, 4-CH 3), 7.85 (s, 3H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 150.1 (3-CCH3), 136.3 (5-CCH3), 113.5 (4-CCH3), 70.8 (CH), 12.2, 9.5, 7.8 (3- or 4- or 5-CH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=1.06×10-3 M): Λ 13.1 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 49.9; H, 6.1; N, 20.2. Calc. for C57H84Ag2N20O6: C, 50.3; H, 6.2; N, 20.6%. IR (cm-1): 3144 w [ν(CH)], 1320 sbr, 1310 s, 729 s [ν(NO3)].

[(AgSO3CH3)2{(3,4,5-Me3pz)3CH}3] (9)

Compound 9 (95% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 8. M.p.: 146 °C (dec.). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.86 (s, 54H, 3- and 5-CH 3), 2.34 (s, 27H, 4-CH 3), 2.82 (s, 6H, SO3CH 3), 7.89 (s, 3H, CH). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=1.17×10-3 M): Λ 47.7 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 50.2; H, 6.7; N, 17.7; S, 4.2. Calc. for C59H90Ag2N18O6S2: C, 49.6; H, 6.4; N, 17.7; S, 4.5%. IR (cm-1): 3098 w [ν(CH)].

[(AgNO3)2{(4-Mepz)3CH}3]⋅(H2O) (11)

Compound 11 (69% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 8 using CH(4-Mepz)3 as ligand. M.p.: 118-119 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.68 (br, 2H, H 2O), 2.01 (s, 27H, 4-CH 3), 7.40 (s, 9H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.74 (s, 9H, 3- or 5-CH), 9.19 (s, 3H, CH). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=1.01×10-3 M): Λ 2.76 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 41.4; H, 4.6; N, 24.6. Calc. for C39H50Ag2N20O7: C, 41.6; H, 4.5; N, 24.9%. IR (cm-1): 3412 br [ν(H2O)], 3078 br [ν(CH)], 1360 sbr, 722 s [ν(NO3)].

[Ag{(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz)CH}2]ClO4 (13)

Compound 13 (67% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 1 using HC(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) as ligand. M.p.: 269-271 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.12 (s, 12H, 3-CH 3), 2.37 (s, 6H, 5-CH 3), 6.12 (br, 6H, 4-CH), 7.55 (s, 2H, 3-CH), 7.93 (s, 4H, 5-CH), 8.64 (s, 2H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 152.2 (3-CCH3 (pz)), 142.1 (3-C (pz)), 141.8 (5-CCH3 (pz)), 133.3 (5-C (pz)), 107.4 (4-C (pz)), 77.7 (CH), 14.4, 11.5 (3- and 5-CH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=0.94×10-3 M): Λ 12.16 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 43.1; H, 4.6; N, 23.2. Calc. for C26H32AgClN12O4: C, 43.4; H, 4.5; N, 23.3%. IR (cm-1): 3142 br, 3122 s [ν(CH)], 1094 sbr, 1056 sbr, 622 s [ν(ClO4)].

[Ag(NO3){(pz)3CH}]H2O (2)

Compound 2 (81% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 1 by using benzene as solvent. M.p.: 177-178 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.63 (br, 2H, H 2O), 6.38 (pt, 3H, 4-CH), 7.67, 7.70 (2 d, 6H, 3- and 5-CH), 8.67 (s, 1H, CH). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=0.90×10-3 M): Λ 0.38 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 30.1; H, 2.6; N, 24.0. Calc. for C10H12AgN7O4: C, 29.9; H, 3.0; N, 24.4%. IR (cm-1): 3400 br [ν(H2O)], 3106 br [ν(CH)], 1398 sh, 1372 sbr, 720 s [ν(NO3)]. Material for the diffraction study, devoid of water, was crystallized from benzene.

[AgClO4(4-Mepz)3CH] (10)

Compound 10 (35% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 1 using CH(4-Mepz)3 as ligand. M.p.: 203 °C (dec.). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.02 (s, 9H, 4-CH 3), 7.41 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.77 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 8.76 (s, 1H, CH). 1H NMR (CD3OD): δ 2.07 (s, 9H, 4-CH 3), 7.53 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.79 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 8.78 (s, 1H, CH). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 2.00 (s, 9H, 4-CH 3), 7.47 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.65 (s, 3H, 3- or 5-CH), 8.71 (s, 1H, CH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 141.8 (3-CH), 128.6 (5-CH), 116.6 (4-CCH3), 81.1 (CH), 8.5 (4-CCH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=1.06×10-3 M): Λ 2.72 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 34.0; H, 3.6; N, 18.1. Calc. for C13H16AgClN6O4: C, 33.7; H, 3.5; N, 18.1%. IR (cm-1): 3149 br, 3113 s [ν(CH)], 1130 sh, 1098 sbr, 1076 sbr, 624 s, 604 s [ν(ClO4)].

[(AgSO3CH3)2{(4-Mepz)3CH}3]⋅(H2O)2 (12)

Compound 12 (33% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 3 using CH(4-Mepz)3 as ligand. M.p.: 118 °C (dec.). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.66 (br, 4H, H 2O), 1.99 (s, 27H, 4-CH 3), 2.92 (s, 6H, SO3CH 3), 7.38 (s, 9H, 3- or 5-CH), 7.87 (s, 9H, 3- or 5-CH), 9.26 (s, 3H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 143.4 (3-CH), 130.5 (5-CH), 117.6 (4-CCH3), 80.0 (CH), 39.4 (SO3CH3), 8.7 (4-CCH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=0.86×10-3 M): Λ 3.02 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 40.4; H, 4.8; N, 20.6; S, 5.5. Calc. for C41H58Ag2N18O8S2: C, 40.7; H, 4.8; N, 20.8; S, 5.3%. IR (cm-1): 3400 br [ν(H2O)], 3093 br [ν(CH)].

[(AgNO3)2(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz)CH}3]⋅H2O (14)

Compound 14 (75% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 8 using CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) as ligand. M.p.: 241 °C (dec.). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.65 (br, 2H, H 2O), 2.15 (s, 18H, 3-CH 3), 2.46 (s, 9H, 5-CH 3), 6.10 (s, 9H, 4-CH), 7.55 (s, 3H, 3-CH), 8.10 (s, 6H, 5-CH), 9.06 (s, 3H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 151.8 (3-CCH3 (pz)), 141.7 (3-C (pz)), 141.3 (5-CCH3 (pz)), 133.1 (5-C (pz)), 106.9, 106.8 (4-C (pz)), 76.7 (CH), 13.4, 10.8 (3- and 5-CH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=0.86×10-3 M): Λ 8.66 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 41.4; H, 4.6; N, 24.6. Calc. for C39H50Ag2N20O7: C, 41.6; H, 4.5; N, 24.9%. IR (cm-1): 3400 br [ν(H2O)], 3126 w, 3102 br [ν(CH)], 1317 sbr, 768 s [ν(NO3)].

[Ag{(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz)CH}2]SO3CH3⋅H2O (15)

Compound 15 (50% yield) was obtained similarly to compound 3 using HC(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) as ligand. M.p.: 249 °C (dec.). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.8 (br, 2H, H 2O), 2.14 (s, 12H, 3-CH 3), 2.44 (s, 6H, 5-CH 3), 2.87 (s, 3H, AgCH 3), 6.10 (s, 6H, 4-CH), 7.55 (s, 2H, 3-CH), 8.11 (s, 4H, 5-CH), 9.00 (s, 2H, CH). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 151.4 (3-CCH3 (pz)), 141.4 (3-C (pz)), 141.2 (5-CCH3 (pz)), 132.9 (5-C (pz)), 106.9, 106.7 (4-C (pz)), 77.2 (CH), 39.7 (SO3CH3), 13.9, 11.1 (3- and 5-CH3). Cond. (CH2Cl2, conc.=1.09×10-3 M): Λ 3.17 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1. Anal. Found: C, 43.8; H, 5.1; N, 22.6; S, 4.6. Calc. for C27H37AgN12O4S: C, 44.2; H, 5.1; N, 22.9; S, 4.4%. IR (cm-1): 3450 br [ν(H2O)], 3127 w, 3100 m [ν(CH)].

Structure determinations

For [Ag(NO3){(pz)3CH}](∞/∞), a unique single counter data set was measured (T ca. 295 K; 2θ max=50°) yielding N=4653 independent reflections, N o=2253 with I>3σ(I) being considered ‘observed', gaussian absorption correction being applied. For [Ag{(3,5-Me2pz)3CH}2]NO3⋅H2O, a full sphere of CCD area detector data was measured (T ca. 153 K; ω-scans, 2θ max=58°), 20 897 reflections merging to N=4581 (R int=0.022) after ‘empirical'/multiscan absorption correction, N o (F>4σ(F))=3757. Anisotropic thermal parameter forms were refined for the non-hydrogen atoms, conventional residuals R, R w (statistical weights) on |F| being quoted. Pertinent results are given in   and     , the latter showing 20 (T ca. 295 K), 50% (T ca. 153 K) displacement amplitudes for the non-hydrogen atoms, hydrogen atoms having arbitrary radii of 0.1 Å.

Crystal/refinement data

[Ag(NO3){(pz)3CH}](∞/∞) (2)

C10H10AgN7O3, M=384.1. Monoclinic, space group P21/n (C 5 2h , No. 14, variant), a=8.842(5), b=30.42(1), c=9.895(4) Å, β=96.14(4)°. V=2646 Å3. D calc (Z=8)=1.928 g cm-3. μ Mo=15.5 cm-1; specimen: 0.09×0.04×0.46 mm. ‘T'min,max=0.89, 0.94. R=0.057, R w=0.053. |Δρ max|=1.85(4) e Å-3. (x, y, z, U iso)H included, constrained at estimated values.

[Ag{(3,5-Me2pz)3CH}2]NO3⋅H2O (5)

C32H46AgN13O14, M=784.7. Monoclinic, space group P21/c (C 5 2h , No. 14), a=8.9162(8), b=12.498(1), c=16.221(2) Å, β=92.321(1)°. V=1806 Å3. D calc (Z=2)=1.443 g cm-3. μ Mo=6.1 cm-1; specimen: 0.16×0.14×0.10 mm. ‘T'min,max=0.80, 0.89. R=0.025, R w=0.033. |Δρ max|=0.57(3) e Å-3. (x, y, z, U iso)H refined (H2O excepted).

cln_elements.content:
In the latter compound, as modeled in space group P21/c, the nitrate was modeled as disordered about a center of symmetry, its disorder concerted with that of a companion water molecule at the symmetry related site. Available specimens were rather small, the present CCD determination being preceded by an inferior room temperature study with data from a single counter instrument, no non-trivial differences being found between the two studies. At approximately 295 K, a=8.962(2), b=12.819(3), c=16.191(3) Å, β=92.59(2)°, V=1858 Å3, D calc=1.370 g cm−3.Conductivity measurements (see ) were carried out in CH2Cl2 for all the derivatives 1–15. The derivatives of CH(pz)3 and CH(4-Mepz)3 are non-electrolytes in CH2Cl2 whereas those of CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 and CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3, the most basic and the most sterically hindered ligands, exhibit conductivity values in CH2Cl2 typical of a 1:1 electrolyte. Finally the derivatives of CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) 13 and 14 are partly ionized in CH2Cl2 solution whereas the derivative 15 is a non-electrolyte in the same solvent. The 2:1 complexes 3–6 and 15 for which an ionic structure has been hypothesized in the solid state likely undergo a dissociation with concomitant re-association of the O-donor coordinating anion (). (2) [(L)2 Ag]+[X]− →
    solvent
[LAgX]+L The perchlorato derivatives 4, 7 and 13, having a 2:1 ligand to metal ratio, show a strong and broad absorption at approximately 1100–1080 cm−1, and a sharp medium or strong absorption at approximately 625 cm−1. These vibrations indicate the presence of ionic perchlorato groups in accordance with the proposed structures (see below). On the other hand, the perchlorato derivatives 1 and 10, with 1:1 ligand to metal ratio show two or three strong and broad absorptions at approximately 1130–1070 cm−1 and sharp medium or strong absorption at approximately 625 cm−1. These vibrations indicate the presence of perchlorato groups coordinated to silver in accordance with the structures proposed. In the spectrum of 1 a broad absorption at approximately 3560 cm−1 is due to the OH stretching of the likely coordinated methanol molecule.

In the latter compound, as modeled in space group P21/c, the nitrate was modeled as disordered about a center of symmetry, its disorder concerted with that of a companion water molecule at the symmetry related site. Available specimens were rather small, the present CCD determination being preceded by an inferior room temperature study with data from a single counter instrument, no non-trivial differences being found between the two studies. At approximately 295 K, a=8.962(2), b=12.819(3), c=16.191(3) Å, β=92.59(2)°, V=1858 Å3, D calc=1.370 g cm-3.

Conductivity measurements (see ) were carried out in CH2Cl2 for all the derivatives 1-15. The derivatives of CH(pz)3 and CH(4-Mepz)3 are non-electrolytes in CH2Cl2 whereas those of CH(3,5-Me2pz)3 and CH(3,4,5-Me3pz)3, the most basic and the most sterically hindered ligands, exhibit conductivity values in CH2Cl2 typical of a 1:1 electrolyte. Finally the derivatives of CH(3-Mepz)2(5-Mepz) 13 and 14 are partly ionized in CH2Cl2 solution whereas the derivative 15 is a non-electrolyte in the same solvent. The 2:1 complexes 3-6 and 15 for which an ionic structure has been hypothesized in the solid state likely undergo a dissociation with concomitant re-association of the O-donor coordinating anion ().  (2) [(L)2 Ag]+[X]-  →  solvent  [LAgX]+L    

The perchlorato derivatives 4, 7 and 13, having a 2:1 ligand to metal ratio, show a strong and broad absorption at approximately 1100-1080 cm-1, and a sharp medium or strong absorption at approximately 625 cm-1. These vibrations indicate the presence of ionic perchlorato groups  in accordance with the proposed structures (see below). On the other hand, the perchlorato derivatives 1 and 10, with 1:1 ligand to metal ratio show two or three strong and broad absorptions at approximately 1130-1070 cm-1 and sharp medium or strong absorption at approximately 625 cm-1. These vibrations indicate the presence of perchlorato groups coordinated to silver in accordance with the structures proposed. In the spectrum of 1 a broad absorption at approximately 3560 cm-1 is due to the OH stretching of the likely coordinated methanol molecule.
